image.altText: Building erupts into flames in Gaza

items.synopsis: Palestinian militants launch a major attack against Israel, prompting Israel's military to strike targets in the Gaza Strip. Follow live.

title.children: Israel cuts power to Gaza as Hamas takes dozens of soldiers hostage

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Israel says it has ordered its state-run electricity company to halt supply to the Gaza strip. It was confirmed by Energy Minister Israel Katz in a post on X, formerly known as Twitter. "I signed the order instructing the electric company to stop supplying electricity to the Gaza Strip. What was will not be," he says.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Power has been cut to Gaza Strip, Israeli minister says

children.content: Israel says it has ordered its state-run electricity company to halt supply to the Gaza strip.
It was confirmed by Energy Minister Israel Katz in a post on X, formerly known as Twitter.
"I signed the order instructing the electric company to stop supplying electricity to the Gaza Strip. What was will not be," he says.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Israeli media, citing rescue service officials, said at least 250 people were killed and 1,500 wounded, making it the deadliest attack in Israel in decades. At least 232 people in the Gaza Strip have been killed and at least 1,700 wounded in Israeli strikes, the Palestinian Health Ministry said.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Death toll rises for both Israel and Palestinians

children.content: Israeli media, citing rescue service officials, said at least 250 people were killed and 1,500 wounded, making it the deadliest attack in Israel in decades.
At least 232 people in the Gaza Strip have been killed and at least 1,700 wounded in Israeli strikes, the Palestinian Health Ministry said.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Hamas militant group says it is holding “dozens” of Israeli soldiers captive in the Gaza Strip. A spokesman for the group’s military wing said the soldiers — including some officers — were captured during a surprise infiltration into southern Israel on Saturday. Abu Obedia says the captives were being held in “safe places” and militant tunnels. The Israeli military has confirmed that Israelis were being held in Gaza.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Hamas says it has captured Israeli soldiers

children.content: The Hamas militant group says it is holding “dozens” of Israeli soldiers captive in the Gaza Strip.
A spokesman for the group’s military wing said the soldiers — including some officers — were captured during a surprise infiltration into southern Israel on Saturday.
Abu Obedia says the captives were being held in “safe places” and militant tunnels.
The Israeli military has confirmed that Israelis were being held in Gaza.

image.altText: People taking photos of Uluru

items.synopsis: Cuts to flights and a slow return of international visitors post-COVID have been blamed for a slump in tourist numbers at one of Australia's most famous landmarks.

title.children: NT tourism minister says Australians have 'social responsibility' to visit NT as Uluru tourism struggles

image.altText: Palestine tower in Gaza city collapses

items.synopsis: Israel says it is now at war with Hamas, launching air strikes on Gaza and vowing to inflict an "unprecedented price" after dozens of Hamas militants broke out of the blockaded Gaza Strip and into nearby Israeli towns, killing hundreds and abducting others in an unprecedented operation.

title.children: 'We are at war': Israel retaliates with Gaza strikes after Palestinian militants kill hundreds and take hostages

image.altText: Palestinians wave their national flag and celebrate.

items.synopsis: Israel is responding to the biggest Hamas attack in years, but the seeds of the unrest were sown decades ago.

title.children: Israel and Hamas 'at war': How did we get here and how is it playing out?

image.altText: A man with long hair in a polo shirt stands in front of a pyramid shaped building and flag poles.

items.synopsis: A confidential meeting of the Barkly Regional Council will be held to discuss the actions of its mayor, Jeffrey McLaughlin.

title.children: Outback mayor refusing to resign after video emerges of him pinning Indigenous boy to ground

items.synopsis: Australian law enforcement has started solving missing persons and unidentified remains cases using official police access to private genealogy databases, which combined, hold the DNA records of millions of people around the world.

title.children: It's being called the biggest game-changer in forensic investigations since DNA testing

image.altText: A photo of a man and a woman with their faces scribbled out.

items.synopsis: A letter from a stranger is all it took to spiral Martin into losing control of his own life. The disability royal commission has made recommendations to reform guardianship legislation, including gag laws that prevent Martin from speaking about his experience.

title.children: We can't show you their faces — a royal commission says that needs to change

image.altText: Vertical gardens and a fountain.

items.synopsis: Singapore will soon join Dubai to provide travellers with a more efficient immigration clearance as early as 2024 following an update to its Immigration Bill.

title.children: Singapore to go passport-free but what are the risks and could Australia follow suit?

image.altText: A woman stands next to a busy street while wearing headphones.

items.synopsis: The "silent walking" trend on TikTok has highlighted how much we rely on audio distractions to get us through the day. But is it a problem?

title.children: 'Me and my thoughts? Sounds horrible': What the 'silent walking' trend says about us

image.altText: Two election placard - one for yes, one for no

items.synopsis: The ABC's poll of the polls now puts Yes at an average of 41.2 per cent, well behind No at 58.8 per cent, Casey Briggs writes.

title.children: Voice polls show support lower than that of failed republic referendum

image.altText: An elderly woman in a red headscarf stands in front of a wall of family photos

items.synopsis: Aunty Ruth Hegarty lived through a cruel chapter in Australian history. Now aged 94, she's approaching the Voice vote with optimism for future generations.

title.children: Ruth Hegarty lived through a cruel chapter in Australia's history — but she now has a message of hope

image.altText: A man wearing a broad-brimmed hat stands on a porch with one arm reaching up.

items.synopsis: When Yindjibarndi leader Michael Woodley stood his ground against Andrew Forrest's FMG he had no idea he'd still be fighting for compensation 14 years later. Despite community division and lengthy court battles he's never backed down.

title.children: 'We chose to fight': How an Indigenous leader took on Australia's richest man Andrew Forrest

image.altText: A spacecrafts solar panel is visible in the foreground, a large grey orange asteroid in the background

items.synopsis: The Psyche mission will travel to an asteroid unlike any we've seen. Its investigations could shed light on how the Solar System and the planets formed.

title.children: This asteroid, worth an estimated $15,600 quadrillion, is the target of a new NASA mission

image.altText: Two men sitting at a table, smiling at the camera.

items.synopsis: Before he became Ukraine's commander-in-chief, Volodymyr Zelenskyy was never far from the front lines — these men were there with him, and know a different side to the president.

title.children: The men who know a different side to Volodymyr Zelenzkyy

image.altText: A woman wearing sunglasses, a dark face mask and brown dress makes her way through a press pack with cameras

items.synopsis: Jakarta's police are in the midst of a morality crackdown, raiding porn studios and targeting content creators. But adult performers say it won't do anything to stop Indonesians from accessing porn.

title.children: Siskaeee is risking jail and defying the haters to make OnlyFans content in Indonesia. Here's why

image.altText: Sun setting over Indian Ocean

items.synopsis: Climate researchers at the Bureau of Meteorology hope a new system will prevent situations where some agencies are declaring an El Niño event and others aren't.

title.children: Weather scientists worry fast-warming oceans have warped BoM's El Niño index

image.altText: A man holding his licence in a park

items.synopsis: When Ben was scammed out of footy tickets, he had no idea the people who duped him were about to use his identity to ruin his reputation and scam even more people — including those desperate for Taylor Swift tickets.

title.children: Ben thought getting his identity stolen was bad enough. Then he was accused of scamming others

image.altText: A mother sits on a rug with her four of her children as they read and write on white sheets of paper.

items.synopsis: Thousands of people onshore and offshore are waiting for their asylum applications to be addressed, so what does the government's plan to spend $160 million improving processing speeds mean for those who haven't seen their family for years?

title.children: Shakila is hiding from the Taliban with her five children. A promise by the Australian government has given her hope

image.altText: Colleen Johnstone and Phil Bayley with their son Angus using a laptop computer.

items.synopsis: Angus isn't like most other year 11 students — it takes him a lot longer to read and understand information. His school gave him extra time at his mid-year exams which really helped. The trouble is, at finals, he won't get anywhere near that — and experts say that isn't fair.

title.children: Angus needs more time in exams to help his 'brain think', but he won't get it at his finals — and advocates say that's unfair

image.altText: A blowfly silhouette on a window pane

items.synopsis: Scientists say you can thank warmer weather for the mass of flies this spring and summer.

title.children: 'A real boom in numbers': Why Sydney has become inundated with flies earlier than usual

image.altText: Woman looking at camera

items.synopsis: Wendy Perkins sheds tears of gratitude when she speaks of the charity that helped get her emergency accommodation extended. But many Northern New South Wales flood victims like her still need help.

title.children: Flood support hubs with 'thousands of outstanding cases' plead for more funding

image.altText: An F1 driver, out of his car, surrounded by pit in the pit, being congratulated

items.synopsis: Max Verstappen's place among the best drivers in Formula 1's history has been confirmed with a third drivers' championship.

title.children: Oscar Piastri gets first F1 victory, Verstappen wins world championship

image.altText: Tevita Ikanivere and Ilaisa Droasese clap

items.synopsis: The Rugby World Cup has been an unmitigated disaster for the Wallabies but they can still qualify for the quarterfinals. Here's how.

title.children: How the Wallabies can qualify for the World Cup quarterfinals

image.altText: Joe Biden stands at lecturn

items.synopsis: The Palestinian militant group Hamas has launched the biggest attack on Israel in years in a surprise assault that combined gunmen crossing into several Israeli towns with a heavy barrage of rockets fired from the Gaza Strip.

title.children: US offers 'all appropriate support' to Israel following biggest attack from Hamas in decades

image.altText: A man celebrates after scoring a try in an NRL match

items.synopsis: His 219 appearances is fourth all-time for the league's oldest club and he retired as the most prolific tryscorer in Rabbitohs history.

title.children: South Sydney great Nathan Merritt in hospital on life support

image.altText: A photo of Dr Goringe inside a shed in Pacific with food donations, other members of the community standing behind her.

items.synopsis: Faith leaders from different religions and denominations are coming together to share a strong message about climate change.

title.children: Meet the religious leaders teaming up to fight climate change

image.altText: A man speaking on a timed video recording

items.synopsis: From retail gigs to graduate positions, the one-way virtual job interview is becoming more common — and depending on who you ask, you may have heard some success (and horror) stories.

title.children: One-way virtual job interviews are becoming more common. Here's how to nail them

image.altText: A woman leans her arm on a tree stump in front of a painting of the Aboriginal flag.

items.synopsis: Australia's most decentralised mainland state is expected to deliver a resounding No at the Voice to Parliament referendum. We spoke to voters about what's influencing their decision.

title.children: We asked regional Queenslanders how they'll vote in the Voice to Parliament referendum

items.synopsis: Türkiye's Defence Ministry says all targets belonging to two Kurdish militias were "legitimate targets" for its forces.

title.children: Turkish forces 'neutralise' militants in Syria in overnight attacks as conflict escalates

image.altText: Emergency vehicles hear a burnt-out patch of grass in a field near a large gum tree.

items.synopsis: Police believe the crash near Gundaroo, north of Canberra, killed a man and three children, but the investigation will be slow and difficult.

title.children: 'Difficult undertaking': Investigators sift through burnt wreckage of plane crash that likely killed four people

subjects.title: Air and Space Accidents and Incidents

image.altText: A Tasmanian azure kingfisher sits on a bare branch against a dark background

items.synopsis: Dean has fallen in love with the elusive Tasmanian azure kingfisher, but fears not enough is being done to protect the species, which is one of 14 endangered native birds without a recovery plan.

title.children: It's estimated there are between 250 and 400 of these birds left in the wild — but there's no plan to save them
